metadata.sermon_start_end: It is impossible for me to think of Eden Seminary without at the same time thinking of Lowell Zuck. My first term as a seminarian at Eden was Lowell’s first term in the faculty. Back in those days he was assigned to teach three terms in sequence [...] We will sing that hymn; we will begin with the first verse in German so that we sing in Maya’s Muttersprache. We will sing as we celebrate Lowell and his life with God.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The Bible passage is not the starting point but a secondary illustration for a biographical eulogy. The text is used to 'characterize' the deceased rather than the text being 'recreated into a new, current, proclamatory word.' It fails to identify what is in this passage that can be found nowhere else.
quotes: It is, however, Lowell’s personal style and presence that I want to talk about and celebrate today.
It is not hard to imagine that Paul has in mind Lowell when he wrote those words.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: The preacher must start with the text's own internal logic and 'otherness' rather than using it as a mirror for a human life.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of Greek/Hebrew study or historical-critical engagement with the Ephesian context. The 'exposition' is merely a summary of the passage's moral exhortations applied immediately to the subject of the eulogy.
quotes: Paul wrote to remind the church that anyone who is in Christ has put off the old self...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific theological and historical tension of the Ephesian church to explain why these specific exhortations were necessary.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is highly concrete but misplaced: it applies the text to a dead man rather than the living congregation. It describes a 'new life' in the past tense. It lacks a sharp analysis of the contemporary zeitgeist or the congregation's current 'misery'.
quotes: What Lowell embodied in his long years at the seminary is exactly kindness...
his very person is a reminder and a summons to us about what a new life can look like.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Shift the application from a biographical retrospective to a concrete address of the congregation's current spiritual reality and the 'zeitgeist'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Exposition and application are mixed, but they are mixed in a way that subordinates the Word to the person. The hearer is not drawn into the text; the text is drawn into the memory of Lowell Zuck.
quotes: It is not hard to imagine that Paul has in mind Lowell when he wrote those words.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'movement' of the sermon leads from the text to the hearer's world, rather than from a person to the text.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is heavily weighted toward 'gratitude' and 'redemption' (as a state of being), but 'misery' is almost entirely absent. The 'old self' is mentioned but not diagnosed as a current, threatening reality for the hearer. It is too 'objective' in its praise of the subject.
quotes: He was a man without guile or self-serving agenda, and that is a rare gift in our present world of fear and greed.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The preacher must address the 'misery' of the congregation—the 'old self' that still clings to the hearers—to make redemption necessary.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'seriousness of being lost' is neutralized. The sermon suggests some are 'more easily welcomed' by God because they did the 'work of resonance.' This borders on a denial of the two ways by suggesting a natural affinity between certain personalities and God.
quotes: God welcomes all with abiding presence, but surely there are some who are more easily welcomed, and Lowell is among them...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Reintroduce the radicality of the 'narrow way' and the possibility of being lost, which gives weight to the 'new self'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as a 'friend' and a 'telos' of the tradition, but the sermon's actual telos is the celebration of a human life. Grace is presented more as a 'marking' of a well-lived life than the radical salvation of a sinner outside themselves.
quotes: ...these markings of his life match the mystery of God.
Lord Jesus, thee I will be in life and death!
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Center the sermon on Christ's work as the only basis for the 'new self,' rather than the subject's 'puckish good humor' or 'gentleness'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1100 words, the sermon would last roughly 11 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for theological depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition and the theological diagnosis of the 'old self' to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The text functions as a warm, biographical eulogy rather than a sermon. It fails to prioritize the specific Bible passage as the primary actor, instead using Scripture as a secondary validation for the character of the deceased. The 'misery' of the human condition is absent, and the 'two ways' are obscured by a focus on the subject's natural virtues.
strengths: Concrete characterization: The description of the 'new self' through the lens of a specific life is vivid.
Irenic tone: The sermon successfully communicates the 'irenic' tradition it praises.
weaknesses: Anthropocentric: The focus is on man's character rather than God's Word.
Lack of Misery: The 'old self' is treated as a past hurdle for the deceased, not a present threat to the hearer.
Insufficient length: The duration does not allow for the 'breadth' Dekker demands for depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a commemorative speech that utilizes biblical motifs. It lacks the 'proclamatory' power of a Word that confronts the hearer with the radical choice between the two ways.
